Soup Is Puttin' on the RitzPublished: October 26, 2005TO reintroduce a struggling brand, the Campbell Soup Company is giving consumers a song and dance - literally. A campaign that began this week for the Campbell's Select line of higher-priced soups features the actor John Lithgow singing and dancing in commercials that offer humorous tributes to the brand. The campaign, carrying the theme "Why settle when you can Select," is being created by BBDO Worldwide in New York, part of the Omnicom Group. In the commercials, Mr. Lithgow performs over-the-top songs about Campbell's Select and a new variety, Select Gold Label, that were written by David Yazbek, who also wrote the music and lyrics for the songs Mr. Lithgow performs in his hit Broadway show "Dirty Rotten Scoundrels." Skip to next paragraph Forum: Media, Advertising and Marketing The campaign is the most elaborate send-up of musical comedy to be sponsored by a premium-priced soup brand since 1970, when Stan Freberg presented Ann Miller in a commercial, tap-dancing atop an eight-foot replica of a can of Great American Soup, sold by the H. J. Heinz Company. The Campbell's Select campaign, with a budget estimated at more than $20 million, is part of efforts by giant food marketers to persuade consumers to pay more for products that are presented as being of better quality than ordinary brands. Campbell's Select is priced about twice as high as the Campbell's condensed soups bearing the red-and-white labels, and Select Gold Label is about 15 percent to 20 percent more than Campbell's Select. (Think of the progression as going from Ford to Mercury to Lincoln.) Among other examples of the trend are a new line of premium-priced boxed chocolates from Russell Stover Candies, called Russell Stover Private Reserve; a new sandwich, the Portobello Mushroom Six Dollar Burger, introduced last month by the Carl's Jr. division of CKE Restaurants; and clothing sold by Wal-Mart Stores under brand names like George and Metro 7, which are meant to be more fashionable than the retailer's more prosaic apparel. Campbell Soup has sold Campbell's Select since 1999, when the line, called Home Cookin' upon its debut in 1983, was renamed and restaged. That Select soups are ready to serve (unlike the red-and-white label soups, to which water must be added) is meant to appeal to those who buy soups like Progresso, sold by General Mills. But a sales chart for Campbell's Select resembles a yo-yo's path, according to data from Information Resources, a company that tracks product sales in food, drug and mass-market stores, excluding Wal-Mart (which does provide that data to research services). Sales rose to $205.4 million in Campbell's 2003 fiscal year, from $170.5 million in fiscal 2001, only to fall to $151 million in fiscal 2005. (The fiscal year ends on July 31.) Recent sales growth for the red-and-white and Chunky soup lines "gives us the opportunity to fix the Select brand," said Sean Connolly, vice president and general manager for United States soup at Campbell Soup in Camden, N.J. "In the last 22 years, the brand has changed its label, its look, its name," he added. "That inconsistency has led to an inconsistent level of performance." So now, Campbell's Select is to be positioned as what the company is calling "premium irresistible soup," Mr. Connolly said, because "we know from our research that premium soup represents a tremendous growth opportunity, not only in soup but across numerous categories." With the "Why settle when you can Select" theme, he added, the company is hoping to appeal to a "target audience who we call food lovers, women ages 25 to 54 who are willing to try new products, willing to trade up, by delivering a product that lives up to the promise of irresistible premium-quality taste." That promise is made by Mr. Lithgow in a devil-may-care manner through song-and-dance numbers in the commercials, which are directed by David LaChapelle, known for photography and music video clips. Many of the spots start with Mr. Lithgow on a set presented as his home kitchen, which swings open in the center to reveal a set representing a stylish restaurant-cum-nightclub peopled with the glamorati. "At last, a soup as irresistible as me," Mr. Lithgow declares, tongue firmly in cheek, in a commercial for a Select Gold Label variety called Roasted Red Pepper and Tomato. Among the lyrics to his song: Why settle when you can Select Why not go go for gourmet? Hey, don't be a schlepper, this Roasted Red Pepper Tomato is Restaurant-style soup all the way Mr. Lithgow is "someone who represents fine taste, quality, the essence of the brand, but will not be elitist, better than thou or a snob," said Ed Maslow, senior vice president and senior creative director at BBDO New York. That could have been the impression consumers took from the campaign if the ads had featured a chef, gourmet or celebrity who symbolized good taste, he added, which would not have "felt comfortable in the Campbell's franchise." The Broadway-style presentation is meant as "a celebration of the product that says 'new,' " Mr. Maslow said, and the lyrics are "specific to what the soup is exactly about" without being boring like a recitation of product attributes delivered by "a talking head." The commercials are appearing on broadcast television series like "Ghost Whisperer," "Medium" and "Two and a Half Men" as well as during cable reruns of shows like "Crossing Jordan," "Law & Order" and "Will & Grace." Print advertisements are to appear in magazines in which Campbell Soup typically advertises, like People, as well as in magazines read by the target audience, like Bon Appétit, Food & Wine, Newsweek, O: The Oprah Magazine and Real Simple. Heinz and Mr. Freberg, the humorist turned ad man, beat Campbell Soup by more than three decades to the idea of a commercial for higher-priced soup centered on an elaborate production number. In the Great American Soup commercial, Ms. Miller sang "Let's face the chicken gumbo and dance," accompanied by 20 chorus girls and the Billy May Orchestra while 4,000 jets of water colored red, white and blue gushed behind them. The commercial became so well-known that it was widely mentioned in the obituaries for Ms. Miller, who died in January 2004. Mr. Maslow said that he was "vaguely familiar" with the Great American Soup commercial, adding, "Someone told me about it." "In no way did it influence what we did here," Mr. Maslow said. "What Great American Soup did had nothing to do with this whatsoever." Perhaps there can be an "American Idol"-type contest between the Campbell's Select and Great American Soup spots. The victor could face the winner of a showdown between the look-alike commercials for the Apple iPod and Lugz boots. Earnings at Campbell Soup Climb 63%Published: September 13, 2005By The Associated Press The Campbell Soup Company, whose brands include Pepperidge Farm, V8, Godiva and its namesake soups, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter profit climbed 63 percent, driven by lower marketing costs, higher selling prices and productivity improvements. The company, based in Camden, N.J., said it expected profit would grow 5 percent to 6 percent in the next year. Campbell said it had stabilized the sales of its condensed soups but was struggling to keep sales of its ready-to-serve line growing. Earnings were $96 million, or 23 cents a share, for the three months ended July 31, up from $59 million, or 14 cents a share, a year earlier. The result was 2 cents a share higher than expected by analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial. Excluding one-time gains and charges, the company earned 17 cents a share in the year-ago period. Sales grew 5 percent, to about $1.5 billion, from $1.43 billion last year, helped by price and sales allowances. Campbell Soup Reports Increase in ProfitPublished: May 24, 2005By The Associated Press TRENTON, May 23 - The Campbell Soup Company said Monday that its third-quarter profit inched higher as rising foreign sales of soup and sauces and strong domestic sales of baking and snack products offset weak United States demand for soup and other products. Income for the quarter ended May 1 grew to $146 million, or 35 cents a share, up from $142 million, or 34 cents, in the period a year earlier. That quarter included a gain of $10 million, or 2 cents a share, from the settlement of a class-action lawsuit. The latest results beat the average estimate of 33 cents a share from analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Campbell, which is based in Camden, N.J., also said it had benefited from favorable currency exchange rates and higher prices and sales allowances; it increased United States prices for many soups, sauces and beverages an average of 4.8 percent on Feb. 28. Still, the company said domestic sales of soups, sauces and beverages slipped 2 percent, to $627 million. Sales of baking and snack products jumped 8 percent, to $421 million. International soup and sauce sales grew 6 percent, to $435 million. Shares of Campbell rose 48 cents, or 1.6 percent, to $30.82 in trading Monday on the New York Stock Exchange. Douglas R. Conant, Campbell's chief executive, said that sales of condensed soup, which have been sliding or stagnant for several years, increased 4 percent in the third quarter. Condensed soup, the top-selling product, also rose 4 percent in its second quarter. It's a Bird! It's a Plane! It's a Soup Can in the Sky!Published: April 19, 2005ix years ago, I flew to Texas with one of our sales managers to meet the executive chef of Hooters. I had only been with StockPot for six months. Everything was going swimmingly. We were all nodding and smiling, and I was feeling extremely proud of myself. Then I made the mistake of asking the chef if there was anything else she wanted to know. She asked if our soups began with a base or a stock and I answered that we used a base. I was met with silence. My answer destroyed the moment. The meeting ended soon afterward and we lost the sale. Later, I asked our chef what was wrong with what I said. He explained that a stock starts with roasted bones, and a base is a mix of dehydrated vegetables and spices. The stock is generally considered superior. I said that with a name like StockPot we really needed to start with a stock, and I made him change over 100 soup recipes. He hated me for three months. When I started at the company, the corporate plane stopped in Cincinnati, where I lived, to pick me up and fly me to Seattle. It was my moving day, and I had all of my things with me. The senior executives from Campbell headquarters in Camden, N.J., were on the flight to brief me. I moved around from seat to seat and met with them, one after the other. It was an unusual first day on the job. That was the old plane with red bands around it that identified it as belonging to Campbell. Recently, on a flight in the company's new corporate plane from Philadelphia to Oakland, I got a phone call on the flight and thought to myself, "Do I rock!" I tried to act nonchalant as I strolled to the cockpit to take the call. After I hung up I asked the pilots where we were. All I could see were the clouds and the mountains below. I wanted to know if they navigated by things they recognized. For instance, did they know to take a left at a certain mountain peak? One said no, they mostly used autopilot. My staff knows that they're going to get a ton of assignments when I can download the e-mails I've written during the flight. I always take a spare battery with me on these flights so I can work for hours. Once a flight attendant tapped me on the shoulder to say that someone complained about my fingernails clicking on the laptop keys. You have no idea how difficult it is to type quickly on the pads of your fingers when you have long nails. I'm the passenger the flight attendant has to tell twice to shut down the laptop before landing. If I'm traveling with a colleague he usually says: "They're saying people have to shut equipment down now. Are you going to do it or wait until they tell you a third time?" As told to Patricia R. Olsen.

Food Companies Test Flavorings That Can Mimic Sugar, Salt or MSGPublished: April 6, 2005everal big food and beverage companies are looking at a new ingredient in the battle for health-conscious consumers: a chemical that tricks the taste buds into sensing sugar or salt even when it is not there. Kraft Foods, Nestlé, Coca-Cola and Campbell Soup are all working with a biotechnology company called Senomyx, which has developed several chemicals, most of which do not have any flavor of their own but instead work by activating or blocking receptors in the mouth that are responsible for taste. They can enhance or replicate the taste of sugar, salt and monosodium glutamate, or MSG, in foods. By adding one of Senomyx's flavorings to their products, manufacturers can, for instance, reduce the sugar in a cookie or salt in a can of soup by one-third to one-half while retaining the same sweetness or saltiness. Now, for instance, a 10 3/4-ounce can of Campbell's Home-style chicken soup, which the company says contains two and a half servings, has more than 2,300 milligrams of sodium. That would probably be cut to a little over 1,500 milligrams when the chemical is added. (The government recommends consumption of no more than 2,400 milligrams of sodium a day.) Unlike artificial sweeteners, Senomyx's chemical compounds will not be listed separately on ingredient labels. Instead, they will be lumped into a broad category - "artificial flavors" - already found on most packaged food labels. "We're helping companies clean up their labels," said Senomyx's chief executive, Kent Snyder. Senomyx, based in San Diego, uses many of the same research techniques that biotechnology companies apply in devising new drugs. Executives say that a taste receptor or family of receptors on the tongue or in the mouth are responsible for recognizing a taste. Using the human genome sequence, the company says, it has identified hundreds of those taste receptors. Its chemical compounds activate the receptors in a way that accentuates the taste of sugar or salt. It is still experimenting to determine the most potent compounds, its chief scientist, Mark Zoller, said. While food safety experts applaud efforts to reduce salt, MSG and sugar, they expressed concerns about the new chemicals, saying that more testing needed to be done before these were sold in food. But Senomyx maintains that its new products are safe because they will be used in tiny quantities. Kraft, Nestlé, Coca-Cola and Campbell Soup have contracted with Senomyx for exclusive rights to use the ingredients in certain types of food and beverages, although the companies declined to identify those categories. Elise Wang, an analyst at Smith Barney, said that Kraft was planning to use Senomyx's sweet flavoring to reduce the sugar in powdered beverages like Kool-Aid by one-third. Campbell Soup, she said, is looking at cutting sodium levels by a third with the salt flavoring. "There's applicability for our soups, sauces and drinks like V8," a spokesman for Campbell, John Faulkner, said. A Kraft spokesman declined to offer specifics on the company's relationship with Senomyx, but said that Kraft was committed to reducing the sugar and salt levels in many products. Nestlé and Coke also declined to comment. Senomyx's salt enhancer, in particular, has the potential to be a boon to the food industry. For years, corporate scientists have been looking in vain for ways to reduce sodium levels in packaged food without losing flavor. "It's a real challenge," said Christine M. Homsey, senior research food scientist at Food Perspectives, a consulting firm in Plymouth, Minn. "Nobody's come up with anything even close to ideal." The Center for Science in the Public Interest, an advocacy group based in Washington, is seeking to get the Food and Drug Administration to pay more attention to the high sodium levels in packaged foods. In February, it filed a lawsuit seeking to force the F.D.A. to regulate salt as a food additive. The effort, if successful, could spur companies to limit salt in their products. Mr. Synder said that Senomyx's salt enhancers were still in the development phase and would not appear in foods for at least two years. The company's most advanced product, he said, is its replacement for MSG, which last month received safety approval from the Flavor and Extract Manufacturers Association. He expects food items with this product to appear in supermarkets sometime in the first half of next year. Continued 1 | 2 | Next>>

Soup and Mama McNabb: Marketing Meets RealityPublished: January 21, 2005few weeks ago while watching one of the Donovan McNabb-and-his-mom commercials for Campbell's Chunky Soup, my wife, Griffin, remarked how cute Mother McNabb was, but I knowingly told her the bad news. "That's an actress," I said, "not his mother." Needless to say, Griffin was quite disappointed. I was wrong. That was Wilma McNabb, the true mother of Donovan. But in 2001, her son's first year as part of Chunky's "mama's boys" campaign, an actress portrayed her. It was at that commercial shoot that Wilma, a former nurse, had an epiphany. "I said: 'I can do that. I can do what she's doing,' " she said by telephone yesterday. "I knew all the lines. I'd seen the script." (And, she said, she had always served Campbell's soup at home. "Was there any other?" she said.) The agency that created the campaign - which has featured John Elway, Kurt Warner, Michael Strahan and Terrell Davis with their faux mothers - found Wilma McNabb gregarious and gave her a chance to mother her son and his Philadelphia Eagles teammates with various Chunky flavors. "I remember our agent called and said, 'They want to do something different and they want to use you,' " she said. Now, she is the only mother - real or not - in the campaign, which is part of Campbell's sponsorship that makes it the National Football League's official soup. "She is very good on her feet," said James Caporimo, executive creative director of Young & Rubicam. "We were a little nervous at first. But she turned out to be a star. She's very poised. And there's no question she's gotten better. She's really terrific." The Chunky campaign has merged fiction with the reality of Wilma McNabb's cooking macaroni and cheese ("too much cheese for us older folks") and red beans and rice for her son and teammates. The commercials portray her as the Eagles' den mother, reading stories to players in a hotel room ("John Elway drove 98 yards"), steering the team bus driver away from stopping at a roadside fast-food joint, and knitting scarves and caps for players. "Let's hear a battle cry!" she shouts to players on the sideline in one of the commercials this season. In the other, her son says, "Our team's a family; she's the mom," which prompts the team to douse her with a bucket of Gatorade. "They really got me," she said about the bucket that was dumped on her. "I didn't know they were doing it, so you could see they had the element of surprise." John Faulkner, a spokesman for Campbell's, said that the McNabb commercials "resonate because of the very public role she plays with the team." The homey scenes of Mother McNabb dishing out soup in the Eagles' locker room is a jarring reminder that the less wholesome Terrell Owens-Nicollette Sheridan opening to "Monday Night Football" was filmed in the same locale. But no soup for T. O.! Although Donovan is the undisputed family star, Wilma, who is better known as Charlene (her middle name), or Char the Star, is easily recognized. She is usually visible on television during games, watching from a luxury box at Lincoln Financial Field. People ask her to repeat her "battle cry" exhortation, and she said that when she travels with the Eagles, rival fans say: " 'Oh, here's Miss Chunky.' It's intimidation with Chunky." She said, "This is fun, but I don't like the notoriety." Campbell's does not offer sales figures to back the Donovan-Wilma effect on Chunky sales, but Caporimo of Young & Rubicam said he was pleased that the soup giant had given the players-and-their-mothers campaign time to develop since 1997. "A lot of clients don't give the time for a campaign to gain traction," he said. "It's like a snowball and it builds." He added that the agency was not unhappy when references to the Chunky Soup Curse cropped up because of injuries to Davis, Warner and, yes, McNabb. Perhaps, some online wags suggested, it was vengeance wreaked by the use of fake moms over real ones. "When it becomes part of the vernacular, it's more than a commercial," Caporimo said. Bob Dorfman, the executive creative director of Pickett Advertising, who analyzes athletes' marketing appeal, said the commercials used humor effectively, sold Chunky as a "hearty meal" for people as large as a football player and were not shown so often that the audience got tired of the message. Now, as she has since she first got the Chunky gig, Wilma McNabb will wait until after the Super Bowl to see if Campbell's wants her back for another season. A New Account for GoldfishPublished: November 24, 2004LARGE client of Young & Rubicam Advertising in New York, the Campbell Soup Company, has quietly decided to seek ideas to promote a major product line from a far smaller agency specializing in unconventional creative approaches. Advertising, part of the Young & Rubicam Brands division of the WPP Group, has handled since 1998. Although Y.& R. Advertising remains the agency of record for Goldfish, as it does for other Pepperidge Farm products, it is now BrightHouse Live's assignment to present Pepperidge Farm with what the company hopes will be the next clever campaign. Advertisement The decision by Pepperidge Farm is the first such step affecting the Campbell Soup account at Y.& R. Advertising, which also includes brands like Pace salsa, Chunky soup, V8 beverages and Prego pasta sauces. The move is emblematic of the attempts by big marketers to search beyond the usual suspects for more effective selling strategies. Marketers besides Campbell Soup that are expanding their agency relationships in unexpected directions include Anheuser-Busch, BMW, Burger King, Coca-Cola, Procter & Gamble and Unilever. "We have a very solid relationship with Y.& R.," Nan Redmond, director for corporate and brand communications at Pepperidge Farm in Norwalk, Conn., said yesterday. "There has been no realignment of agency-of-record status," she added, "but now BrightHouse Live is working on developing some new creative communication directions for the Goldfish brand." "There's a special strategic direction here we're looking to," Ms. Redmond said, which she declined to discuss, citing competitive reasons, "and we felt it requires additional capabilities." Neither Pepperidge Farm nor BrightHouse Live previously disclosed the agency's new role on Goldfish. After this reporter received an e-mail message last week from an unfamiliar address discussing the decision, Ms. Redmond confirmed it, as did executives of Y.& R. Advertising and BrightHouse Live. "We've been doing it for a couple of months," said Michael Edmeades, who joined BrightHouse Live as president when it was opened in November 2003 by BrightHouse, a strategic consultant described by its founder, the adman Joey Reiman, as an "ideation corporation." Mr. Edmeades said Goldfish was the first packaged-goods assignment for BrightHouse Live, which he called "a hybrid between an advertising agency and a marketing consultancy." BrightHouse Live also has clients like the ESPN cable television network. Pepperidge Farm spent $6.5 million to advertise Goldfish in major media during the first eight months of the year, according to TNS Media Intelligence/CMR, a division of Taylor Nelson Sofres, compared with $11.1 million in the period a year ago. For all of 2003, spending totaled $16.3 million, TNS reported, almost unchanged from $16.7 million in 2002. Pepperidge Farm sells more than a dozen varieties of Goldfish, from the traditional orange-colored fish-shaped crackers to exotic styles like Baby Goldfish, Giant Goldfish, Flavor Blasted Goldfish and Goldfish Colors. The data include sales in supermarkets, drugstores and mass-merchandise chains except for Wal-Mart Stores. Goldfish marketing was fairly prosaic for many years, and sales had been flat, until 1995, when Pepperidge Farm tried new advertising, additional varieties and improved distribution. The agency then was Saatchi & Saatchi in New York, which lost the Goldfish assignment along with the other Pepperidge Farm products in 1998 to Y.& R. Advertising in a consolidation by Campbell Soup. The most recent work for Goldfish from Y.& R. Advertising, Ms. Redmond said, has been aimed at the so-called tween market, ages 8 to 12, as well as teenagers. One campaign reintroduced Flavor Blasted Goldfish with new flavors and packages. The data from Information Resources showed a 43.4 percent increase in dollar sales of the line in the 52 weeks that ended Oct. 31. Another recent campaign, Ms. Redmond said, introduced Goldfish Sandwich Snackers, two crackers with fillings between in flavors like cheddar cheese and peanut butter. In September 2003, Y.& R. Advertising brought out a major campaign for the Pepperidge Farm brand that introduced an animated character, a driver of a Pepperidge Farm truck, meant to personify brand traits like quality and freshness. Liz Reilly, a spokeswoman for Y.& R. Advertising, said the agency has had "extreme success with the Campbell brands" it handles. Y.& R. Advertising has been closely watched since Ann Fudge, an executive with a background in packaged-goods marketing, joined Y.& R. Brands last year as chairwoman and chief executive. Company Shows Argentina How to Shake Its IsolationPublished: September 14, 2004UENOS AIRES - In the summer of 2001, just as the worst economic crisis in Argentina's history was coming to a boil, Paul H. O'Neill, then the United States Treasury secretary, set off a furor here by suggesting that the country might have avoided collapse had it ever bothered to learn to export. The real trouble with Argentina, Mr. O'Neill told The Economist, is that "they don't have any export industry to speak of at all." He added: "And they like it that way." While Argentina is still far from becoming a trade powerhouse, one company that has bucked the trend for decades by successfully selling abroad is Swift Armour S.A. Argentina, the country's leading meat products company. Unlike most of its domestic rivals, Swift generates more than 70 percent of its sales through exports, and inward-looking Argentina desperately needs the dollars earned by exports to stabilize its large debt. Run by Carlos Oliva Funes, a soft-spoken executive with more than three decades of experience in the beef business, Swift is generating jobs and setting an example for other Argentine companies that are seeking to increase sales by tapping into foreign markets. The company has added almost 1,000 people to its payroll since 1999, bringing its work force to 2,570; during that time many of its competitors cut workers. And at the government's urging, Swift is now sharing some of its expertise with smaller companies that want to export tea, honey, olive oil and other products. "Swift has always gotten the bulk of its revenue from exports, and that's helped us weather the ups and downs of the economy," Mr. Oliva Funes, 61, said in an interview at the company's headquarters in downtown Buenos Aires. "It's worked well for us, so we're sponsoring some small companies to try and teach them a little bit about how to export so they can do the same." Founded in 1907, Swift has long been a big name in Argentina's beef industry, employing as many as 23,000 people after the government briefly took over the company in the early 1970's. Swift became a private company again in 1977 when a local investment group led by Mr. Oliva Funes bought it and set out to streamline it to make it more profitable. Three years later, a smaller but more efficient Swift changed hands again when the Argentines sold out to the Campbell Soup Company of Camden, N.J., though Mr. Oliva Funes stayed on as a director. For most of the next two decades, Swift thrived as one of Campbell's biggest suppliers of frozen and canned beef, used to make soups. In 1997, Campbell's transferred control of Swift to a subsidiary, Vlasic Foods International, which was spun off as an independent company a year later. But Vlasic soon decided to abandon its commodity businesses and focus on its operations in the United States, and it put Swift up for sale in 1999. Hoping to seize the chance to buy the company back, Mr. Oliva Funes started hunting for investors. Before long, he brought on board two Wall Street private equity funds, J. P. Morgan Latin America Capital Partners and Greenwich Street Capital Partners, which divided up a 49 percent stake in Swift. With the help of Argentine investors, Mr. Oliva Funes raised $55 million and took a 51 percent stake in the company. Swift got off to a rocky start under new ownership. The company was hit hard by a drop in beef prices after outbreaks of mad cow disease in Europe and of bovine hoof-and-mouth disease in Argentina. Brazil's decision to devalue its currency in early 1999 also hurt Swift's earnings, making Brazilian beef more competitive on world markets. The Argentine peso was still pegged to the American dollar at that time. By 2003, Swift's sales had dropped to $137 million a year from $160 million in 1999. To weather the storm, Swift sealed long-term contracts with big buyers like Campbell's and Kraft Foods, and actively sought out new clients around the globe. Today the company exports beef products to 70 countries and is on track to report more than $200 million in sales this year. "We used to be a reliable supplier for Campbell's Soup," Mr. Oliva Funes said. "Now we're a reliable supplier for a variety of companies all over the world." Swift's aggressiveness also helped it ride out Argentina's economic crisis better than most. When the Argentine economy collapsed in late 2001 and most investors were pulling money out of the country, Swift went on a buying spree. In 2002, Swift spent $4 million to buy Cabaña Las Lilas, one of Argentina's best-known brands of premium beef. A few months later, it snapped up a bankrupt meatpacking plant near the Uruguayan border named Vizental for $8 million, which increased its production capacity by about 35 percent. "In the middle of the crisis, instead of pulling back, what we did was raise our bet by going out and buying more assets," said Alfredo M. Irigoin, a partner in the Buenos Aires office of JPMorgan Partners, the private equity arm of J. P. Morgan Chase & Company. "But if Swift hadn't been such an exporter, forget it, it wouldn't have paid off." Other Argentine companies are starting to follow Swift's example, taking advantage of a weak peso to export. The government expects export revenues to grow 14 percent this year to a record $33.5 billion, though this is mostly because of a jump in prices for commodities like soybeans and oil. Brazil, by contrast, is on track to bring in more than $90 billion from exports this year. But most companies here, especially the smaller ones, still face formidable obstacles to becoming exporters. Credit remains scarce and costly, making it hard for companies to market their products to potential overseas buyers. With a few exceptions, foreign investors have been reluctant to fill that void, preferring to wait and see if Argentina's economic recovery is sustainable. Moreover, the government, strapped for cash, levies taxes of up to 45 percent on exports to help pay the country's huge public-sector debt, currently equivalent to about 127 percent of gross domestic product. "There are several companies doing a good job at exporting, but it has taken years of persistence," said Enrique S. Mantilla, the president of the Chamber of Exporters of Argentina. "There's talent here, but it's not easy to put that talent to use in a country with so much volatility."

MEDIA; Products Slide Into More TV Shows, With Help From New MiddlemenPublished: September 6, 2004Leslie Moonves loves to talk about the Steven Spielberg movie ''Minority Report.'' Mr. Moonves, the co-president and co-chief operating officer of Viacom, which owns CBS, Paramount Television and Showtime, still sings the praises of the movie two years after he saw it. But it was not the cinematography or Tom Cruise's star turn that moved him. It was all the brand names -- Lexus, Gap, Reebok, Guinness and American Express -- that found their way into the film. ''That movie was packed with brands,'' he said. ''I sat in the movie theater and thought A, the movie's working, and B, if Spielberg can do it without compromising the artistry, we can, too.'' Television networks have worked hard in the last two years to strike their own product placement deals, closing the gap with the movies. CBS plans to broadcast product-themed nights, with a single brand featured on consecutive shows, although Mr. Moonves declined to offer details. Entire episodes of NBC's ''The Apprentice'' will revolve around one brand: instead of selling lemonade or giving rickshaw rides, the aspiring business tycoons will sell Mars's newest candy bar, hawk Crest toothpaste and construct a new toy for Mattel. Campbell's Soup has been written into ''American Dreams,'' with NBC and the soup maker sponsoring a real-life essay contest mirroring one in the show's plot. The new emphasis on product placement in television has brought new players into the business -- brand wranglers who work with programmers and advertisers. They are pushing the placement, which they like to call ''brand integration,'' into new territory, sometimes acting as co-producers and even building new programming around the brands. ''There's been a gold rush that reminds me of the Internet 10 years ago,'' said Scott Donaton, editor of Advertising Age and the author of ''Madison & Vine,'' a book about the convergence of the entertainment and advertising industries. ''Many went to the advertisers and said, 'You can't handle Hollywood. Let me do it for you.' Then they went to the networks and promised to handle the advertisers.'' Some of the new integrators are traditional product placement firms, while others are advertising agencies that have started entertainment divisions. New companies devoted to product integration have also popped up. All see the chance to profit from the growing closeness between programmers and advertisers, who have been forced to band together to counter falling ratings, a fragmented audience and new technology like digital video recorders that allow viewers to skip traditional commercials altogether. Madison Road Entertainment, which calls itself an independent, advertiser-driven television studio, is one of the newest players. The two-year-old Los Angeles company was created by Tom Mazza, the former president of Columbia TriStar Television; Jak Severson, a longtime marketing executive; and Rob Long, a former writer for ''Cheers.'' The company worked on some of this season's highest-profile product integration deals -- for example, helping bring Levi's, Crest and Mars to the ''The Apprentice.'' Madison Road also struck a deal to brand the photo shoots that cap episodes of UPN's ''America's Next Top Model,'' and its executives said they had a deal in the works for the Fox Network's ''Bernie Mac'' show. But the small company is hunting much bigger game. Madison Road is aiming to create what programmers and advertisers call branded entertainment, working products into the fabric of a show from the start of its development. ''The best way to bridge these two worlds, who often speak very different languages, is to come in at the very beginning of the creative process,'' the president of the company, Mr. Mazza, said. He said a cable channel had ordered a pilot for a branded show created by Madison Road, and that six others were in development. He would not discuss details. Alliance, the product placement arm of the advertising company Grey Global, is moving aggressively into the product integration business. Its chief executive, Jarrod Moses, recently brokered a deal for the Hasbro game ''Operation'' game to be written into NBC's medical show ''Scrubs.'' Now he is pushing the company further.

There was a shy girl of about 6 who would sit on the bench and watch me the whole two hours, from 5 to 7 p.m. After a few days, I asked if she would like to try.At first she couldn't even catch a ball with two hands. By the end of the summer, she was able to hit a backhand solidly while on the move. I gave her an old racquet I had, and she'd hit the ball against the fence while I gave lessons. The more she could hit the ball, the more I saw her self-esteem grow. It turned out that she had great athletic ability.I have taught tennis to my wife, Leigh, too, but in turn she has enhanced my creative side. When one of my former employers, Parker Brothers, was sold and I had to look for a job, the company sent me to a handwriting expert and said I could bring my wife. I've had hundreds of hours of management training, and I got more out of that one hour than from all those courses. The expert told us to write a couple of sentences for her to analyze. While I wrote mundane things like ''My name is . . .'' my wife wrote part of a Shakespeare sonnet. Our conversation with the expert highlighted how incredibly richer my life is because of what my wife has exposed me to.On my first day at my first job, with General Mills in Minneapolis, I was still tan from teaching tennis. I had long hair and a Fu Manchu mustache and a tan line where my sweatband had been. I wore a khaki suit, a yellow shirt, a madras tie and Earth Shoes. After I looked around and saw what other employees looked like, I made a quick trip to a clothing store.My first assignment was to write the message from Betty Crocker on the back of the potato-bud package. My mother thought this was hilarious. She was from the South and believed in home cooking. We always had rice or freshly mashed potatoes. First, she asked: ''What's a product manager?'' And then: ''What do you know about Betty Crocker?''In business as in tennis, I love to win. I tell people two things. First, if you've committed to something, you'd better deliver.Second, don't be a pain. Just as Tom Hanks said in the movie ''A League of Their Own'' that there's no crying in baseball, there's no whining in business.

Campbell Soup responds to Progresso attacks ads.Published: March 07, 2001THE empire of soup is striking back.The Campbell Soup Company, seeking to stem further erosion of its once-commanding lead in the American soup market, is beginning to respond to assertive attack advertising that has been appearing for more than two years on behalf of its primary rival, the Progresso brand of soups sold by the Pillsbury Company unit of Diageo P.L.C. Ms. Walters's production company, Barwall Productions, is a co-owner of the program with ABC.Integrated advertising campaigns, staples of television in its early days, are not uncommon now. The results showed that the beans could induce an allergic reaction. Knowing that allergic reactions to Brazil nuts were on the order of one in 100,000 and that the number of potential deaths from eating the beans would be less than two a year, the company canceled its soy bean program. That's what Mr. Flanagan should have told us. If Campbell's vegetables contain Brazil nut genes, fish genes or antibiotic marker genes, he should say so. Innuendo is uncalled for.MELVIN A. Food Companies Urged to End Use of Biotechnology ProductsPublished: July 20, 2000A coalition of consumer and environmental groups announced yesterday what they hope will be the biggest and best-organized effort yet in the United States to pressure food companies to abandon the use of genetically modified crops.Starting with the Campbell Soup Company, the coalition said it would target well-known food companies and try to generate thousands of consumer letters, phone calls and signatures on petitions urging them to stop using genetically modified foods until more testing was done. The group also wants all companies to label products that contain such ingredients.In Europe, food companies have largely abandoned the use of such ingredients because of consumer opposition fanned by aggressive campaigns. But in the United States, consumers have expressed little concern about genetically modified foods and many are not even aware that such foods are being sold.''This is going to be the first sort of sustained effort on the European model,'' said Philip E. Clapp, president of the National Environmental Trust, one of the groups in the coalition, the Genetically Engineered Food Alert.The coalition could spend $1 million, or more, he said. That is still considerably below the $50 million a group of agricultural biotechnology companies committed in April to spend over several years on television advertising and other measures to defend their products.The group has named no other targets yet than Campbell. But Jean Halloran of Consumers Union, which is cooperating with the coalition though not a member, said the coalition would choose ''corporations that have food products that Americans really regard as staples of their kitchen, that they feed to their kids.'' Besides soup, Campbell makes Pepperidge Farm cookies, V8 juice, Prego pasta sauce and Godiva chocolates.John Faulkner, a Campbell's spokesman, said the company saw no need to eliminate genetically engineered ingredients because they were as ''equally nutritious and equally safe'' as nonmodified ones. He said that fewer than one-tenth of 1 percent of calls to the Campbell's consumer hotline concerned genetic engineering. And even if Campbell wanted to eliminate such ingredients, he said, it could not, because a large percentage of the corn and soybeans grown in the United States is genetically altered. ''We don't control the supply chain,'' he said.

THE MARKETS: Market Place; A Higher Bid Puts Pressure On BestfoodsPublished: June 06, 2000The board of Bestfoods met last night to discuss a sweetened takeover offer of about $20 billion, or $72 a share, from Unilever amid increasing pressure from shareholders to sell the company.At the same time, Bestfoods was pursuing a $15 billion purchase of the Campbell Soup Company, the beleaguered maker of canned soups that has been struggling to expand its business over the last several years. That offer for the maker of Skippy peanut butter, Thomas' English muffins, Entenmann's baked goods and Knorr soups was up from the $61 to $64 originally offered in April. At the time, the board of Bestfoods unanimously rejected the plan, saying the price was inadequate and that it did not think it was ''opportune to consider a sale of the company.''Both Niall FitzGerald and Antony Burgmans, the co-chairmen of Unilever, arrived in New York on Friday and have been waiting anxiously for breakthroughs in their bid to acquire Bestfoods. BRIEFING: SOUP MAKER; CAMPBELL SOUPPublished: May 21, 2000Campbell Soup Company, the world's largest soup maker, last week reported a 14 percent drop in fiscal third quarter earnings and said full-year results may miss forecasts because of weak demand for its soups. The maker of Campbell's Soup, Pepperidge Farm cookies and crackers and V8 vegetable drinks said earnings fell to $139 million, or 32 cents per diluted share, in the third quarter ended April 30, from $162 million, or 37 cents, in the same period a year ago. Nelson issued a ''sell'' rating on Campbell shares in April. The decline in third-quarter profits and the gloomy outlook came as little surprise to many industry analysts who had lowered earnings estimates in recent weeks after trade figures showed Campbell's soup sales fell sharply during the quarter.
